title: conftree
code: set.seed(123) groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = forest,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.1,   gamma = 0.01,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 4 )

title: conftree
code: groups #> Conformal tree with 4 subgroups: #> [1] root #> |   [2] weekday in Sun, Sat: * #> |   [3] weekday in Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri #> |   |   [4] year in 0 #> |   |   |   [5] month <= 3.5: * #> |   |   |   [6] month > 3.5: * #> |   |   [7] year in 1: * #> --- #> * terminal nodes (subgroups)

what: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction
title: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction
text: R package finds robust subgroups data single continuous response, suitable either regression treatment effect models. Subgroups identified via recursive partitioning, resulting interpretable tree. Conformal prediction methods (SCR, CV+ Jackknife+) leveraged simultaneously optimize inter-group heterogeneity intra-group homogeneity. First, predictions made using arbitrary regression learner 100+ algorithms available tidymodels. , data split recursively using robust conformal criterion. way, conftree extends R2P algorithm Lee et al. (NeurIPS 2020). Scope: subgroups regression problems r2p() subgroups treatment effects r2p_hte()

title: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction
text: can install current development version GitHub :

title: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction
text: Let’s find subgroups Washington bike share data. use random forest tidymodels learner, 5% miscoverage rate alpha, 10 cv_folds CV+ quantify uncertainty resulting subgroups:
code: library(conftree) library(tidymodels) data(bikes)  set.seed(1234)  # Specify the learner to be used for model training: forest <- rand_forest() %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger")  # Find optimal subgroups: groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = forest,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 4 )  # Display tree structure: groups$tree #> [1] root #> |   [2] weekday in Sun: * #> |   [3] weekday in Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat #> |   |   [4] weekday in Sat: * #> |   |   [5] weekday in Sun, Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri #> |   |   |   [6] temp <= 6.15: * #> |   |   |   [7] temp > 6.15: *  # Plot: plot(groups)

what: conftree: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction — conftree-package
title: conftree: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction — conftree-package
text: Detect subgroups machine learning models numeric outcomes (regression). leverages CV+/Jackknife+ simultaneously optimize inter-group heterogeneity intra-group homogeneity. way, extension r2p algorithm, see Lee et al. (2020) arXiv:2006.07917v2. works learning algorithms regression tasks available 'tidymodels'. conftree detects subgroups via recursive partitioning based confident conformal homogeneity.

title: conftree: Subgroups with Trees using Conformal Prediction — conftree-package

title: Plot a conftree — plot.conftree
code: library(tidymodels) #> ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels 1.2.0 ── #> ✔ broom        1.0.7     ✔ recipes      1.1.0 #> ✔ dials        1.3.0     ✔ rsample      1.2.1 #> ✔ dplyr        1.1.4     ✔ tibble       3.2.1 #> ✔ ggplot2      3.5.1     ✔ tidyr        1.3.1 #> ✔ infer        1.0.7     ✔ tune         1.2.1 #> ✔ modeldata    1.4.0     ✔ workflows    1.1.4 #> ✔ parsnip      1.2.1     ✔ workflowsets 1.1.0 #> ✔ purrr        1.0.2     ✔ yardstick    1.3.1 #> ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────── tidymodels_conflicts() ── #> ✖ purrr::discard() masks scales::discard() #> ✖ dplyr::filter()  masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()     masks stats::lag() #> ✖ recipes::step()  masks stats::step() #> • Search for functions across packages at https://www.tidymodels.org/find/ library(ranger) data(bikes) set.seed(1234) randforest <- rand_forest(trees = 200, min_n = 5) %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger") groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = randforest,   cv_folds = 2,   alpha = 0.1,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 3 ) plot(groups)

title: Print a conftree — print.conftree
code: library(tidymodels) library(ranger) data(bikes) set.seed(1234) randforest <- rand_forest(trees = 200, min_n = 5) %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger") groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = randforest,   cv_folds = 2,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 3 ) print(groups) #> Conformal tree with 2 subgroups: #> [1] root #> |   [2] workingday in False: * #> |   [3] workingday in True: * #> --- #> * terminal nodes (subgroups)

what: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
title: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
text: Finding Subgroups Conformal Trees

title: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
code: r2p(   data,   target,   learner,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.1,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 10 )

title: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
text: data (data.frame) data set model training uncertainty estimation. target (string) name target variable. target must numeric variable. learner (model_spec) learner training prediction model. See parsnip::model_spec() details. cv_folds (count) number CV+ folds. alpha (proportion) miscoverage rate. gamma (proportion) regularization parameter ensuring reduction impurity confident homogeneity sufficiently large. lambda (proportion) balance parameter, quantifying impact average interval length relative average absolute deviation (.e. interval width vs. average absolute deviation) max_groups (count) maximum number subgroups.

title: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
text: tree.

title: Finding Subgroups with Conformal Trees — r2p
code: library(tidymodels) library(ranger) data(bikes) set.seed(1234) randforest <- rand_forest() %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger") groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = randforest,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 10 ) groups$tree #> [1] root: *

what: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
title: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
text: Finding Subgroups Treatment Effects Conformal Trees

title: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
code: r2p_hte(   data,   target,   treatment,   learner,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.1,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 10 )

title: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
text: data (data.frame) data set model training uncertainty estimation. target (string) name target variable. target must numeric variable. treatment (string) name treatment variable. treatment factor, first level treated control second level treatment indicator. treatment numeric, zero-one encoding assumed "1" treated treatment indicator. learner (model_spec) learner training prediction model. See parsnip::model_spec() details. cv_folds (count) number CV+ folds. alpha (proportion) miscoverage rate. gamma (proportion) regularization parameter ensuring reduction impurity confident homogeneity sufficiently large. lambda (proportion) balance parameter, quantifying impact average interval length relative average absolute deviation (.e. interval width vs. average absolute deviation) max_groups (count) maximum number subgroups.

title: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
text: tree.

title: Finding Subgroups in Treatment Effects with Conformal Trees — r2p_hte
code: library(tidymodels) library(ranger) data(bikes) set.seed(1234) randforest <- rand_forest() %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger") groups <- r2p_hte(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   treatment = "year",   learner = randforest,   cv_folds = 10,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 10 ) groups$tree #> [1] root: *

title: Prints summary for a conftree — summary.conftree
code: library(tidymodels) library(ranger) data(bikes) set.seed(1234) randforest <- rand_forest(trees = 200, min_n = 5) %>%   set_mode("regression") %>%   set_engine("ranger") groups <- r2p(   data = bikes,   target = "count",   learner = randforest,   cv_folds = 2,   alpha = 0.05,   gamma = 0.2,   lambda = 0.5,   max_groups = 3 ) summary(groups) #> Conformal tree with 2 subgroups: #>     n   mean  width deviation #> 1 231  49.91  85.53      1.07 #> 2 496 289.73 249.85     13.75 #> --- #> Alpha:  0.05 Lambda:  0.5 Gamma:  0.2
